acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.06mg/L of the fish (Fathead Minnows) (CERI Hazard Data (1997) and others.).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) of 300mg/kg (RTECS (2004)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K (as cadmium and cadmium compounds) by NTP (2005), Group 1 (as cadmium and cadmium compounds) by IARC (1993) and Category 1 (as cadmium and cadmium compounds) by the Japan Society for Occupational Health.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing unsaturated bonds and a distorted ring structure.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
Insufficient data available
As for health hazards, refer to "ID254, Cadmium Chloride, CAS: 10108-64-2."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to the absence of data, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen. Cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate is not listed in the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, while inorganic nitrates (solid) (excluding those with specific product names) are classified into Division 5.1 (Oxidative Solid, UN#1477).

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing unsaturated bonds and a distorted ring structure.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In accordance with the technical guideline, given the fact that the substance is classified into Category 1 of skin corrosion/irritation.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24-hour application) (RTECS (2004)): The substance causes severe skin irritation, though it is unknown whether they are reversible or not. The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (water solubility: 156g (Anhydride Equivalent)/100g (25degC), Lide (84th, 2003))

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
No data available
The chronic toxicity of cadmium compounds includes "renal failure, pulmonary emphysema" (EHC 134 (1992)), "hypercalcinuria, a decrease in blood phosphate levels, nephrolithiasis, osteoporosis, osteomalacia" (CaPSAR (1994)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
No data available
And based on the human evidence including "acute toxicity following inhalation (chemical pneumonia, pulmonary edema) and ingestion (acute/severe nausea, vomiting, gastralgia)" (EHC 134 (1992)) (cadmium compounds).
